title: Primary inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor of stomach—report of a very rare case
patient: A 25-year-old lady presented with pain and swelling in upper abdomen of one-month duration. Pain was dull aching and burning in nature. The swelling was insidious in onset, approximately 10cms in diameter. Her appetite was normal. Upper GI Endoscopy showed external compression from anterior wall of the stomach. Ultrasonography and CECT of abdomen showed a large heterogeneously enhancing mass lesion arising from anterior wall of the body of stomach. Pre-operatively, a diagnosis of GIST (Gastrointestinal stromal tumour) was made. At operation, an exophytic growth emanating from the body and antrum of stomach was seen with no infiltration to adjacent organs was noted. Distal gastrectomy [] with roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy was done. Histopathological [] and immuno-histochemical examinations confirmed the diagnosis of IMT. The tumour was weakly positive for SMA (Smooth muscle actin) and vimentin. CD117, CD34, and S100 were negative.\nPatient recovered well and was doing well till 6 months after surgery.
